text: Spending Christmas with my family when I was little. It makes me feel nostalgic because I dont really spend Christmas with them any more (I mean with my cousins etc). It makes me feel slightly sad and makes me think about the people in it and wonder what they are doing.

Travelling around the Whitsundays in Australia on a boat. Was the most relaxing, carefree and uplifting moment. Can still feel the warmth from the sun, can see the blue sea flowing past beneath me. When I got out on deck at 7am and only one other person was up, and the sun was just rising, it was so calm and peaceful and tranquil. It gave me some time to reflect on my life and make me feel as if anything was possible. We spent the 3 days on the boat snorkelling, swimming, sunbathing and eating good food. The scenery was beautiful and it made me feel incredibly lucky.

I feel nostalgic when I think of my holiday to Rhodes with my three best friends. I feel happy when I think of the fun we had and I smile reliving the events in my mind. I find myself laughing when I think of the tricks we played on the boys we met and the outfits we dressed up in! However I also feel sad that the holiday is over and will never happen again. I feel regretful that Im not as close to those friends as I once was. Thinking about the holiday makes me feel both happy and sad.

When I was seven or eight I remember going on a boating trip with my family. It was summertime, and we would travel to many places along the river. My fondest memory of that time was tying up and all playing badminton in a field beside the river. This brings feelings of warmth and happiness to me, as I am nostalgic about the feeling of freedom experienced only in childhood.

I went to see some bands playing at the union bar on Saturday night. I got a taxi at 7.30 and bought a drink then sat at a table chatting to my friend, whilst listening to the music. We then moved to stand by the stage as the bar got busier. I phoned for a taxi home at 10.45pm. It arrived at 11.30pm so we got in it and arrived home at 11.40pm. I ate toast and drank tea whilst watching TV, then went to bed at about 1am.

Going to school  I often think about when I used to be at school (secondary) in particular. The fun I used to have. I think when youre at school you dont realise how much of a carefree life you have  no worries kind of thing. You never believe your mum at 14 when she says youll want to go back when youve left  but its true. Id just love to go back to school  knowing what I do now. Adolescence seemed so hard, so much heartache for nothing (or so it seems now)  well in reality, I think its almost as though I want that feeling  that carefree  no responsibilities, no debt, no worries feelings that children can have.

When I was 16 I believe I first fell in love, I had all the feelings of giddiness, longing and stomach flips. I hadnt seen the person for a long time and knew that he was returning. I felt nervous and sick, but was still very excited. As the time grew nearer to meeting him I grew even more anxious, but upon seeing him, these feelings soon disappeared. I felt happy and excited and relaxed within his company although still rather excited and nervous about the situation. I believe I refer to this experience a lot as it reminds me of how happy I felt, through the time leading up to and during the event I went through a whole range of emotions from anxiety to feeling ecstatic, resulting in a feeling of overwhelming happiness.

Being in year 11 of high school. It was my last year at school. It was an event where we all left to go onto college. I was living in London, and was moving to Southampton for college, and this meant leaving all my friends. It was a really emotional time, and I feel nostalgic to the good times we had when all of us were together. We had all known each other for 5 years, so we knew each other fairly well, so it was very emotional when we left. It feels sad now, as I havent seen some of them in a few years, and we have all changed and matured. It a way its also sad, by saying bye to being a child!

On holiday in the Caribbean (Antigua). Me, my brother and my dad are at a beach that my dad had driven to. There was no one on the beach or in the water. The water was four or five different colours of blue. It felt like we were in paradise. The sand was white and soft and all you could hear were the waves hitting the shore. It made me feel relaxed and it made me forget about my worries. Me and my brother swam in the water as well. It was warm and calming and it felt like I wanted to stay at this beach forever.

I feel nostalgic when I think back to my GAP year. I taught English to Thai children from the age of 7-8 years. It was such an amazing experience. I grew up a lot and had many insights into different cultures as I lived there for 3 months, then travelled around the world. It was such an exciting time of my life, with no apparent worries. A Levels had finished, universities were sorted out and my friend and I were young and free travelling around the world. It was my first experience of being totally independent and I loved it.

Remembering a school trip to Italy many years ago definitely makes me feel nostalgic. We all had so much fun I cant believe it occurred so long ago. I remember certain aspects of it extremely clearly  the ice cream we ate, the scary bus ride up into the hills, how a group of us went and ate lunch on some rocks by the sea! Back then we were so innocent and its strange to think that were no longer really close friends and that now were travelling going to university, or just trying to make something of our lives. I remember going to a school fair and how my friend and I attracted the boys who loved our ginger and blonde hair. One of them even took a photo of us which I still have and my friend and I laugh when we see it. Its such a comforting feeling to look back and remember the happy times, when you didnt have a care in the world and your whole future ahead of you. In a way it gets quite upsetting but its good to have the memories and photos to remember it.

My holiday in Thailand last month. There are so many different aspects that make me feel nostalgic  the scenery was stunning  powder-white sandy beaches, fringed by coconut palms with electric blue sea like bathwater and a backdrop of striking limestone rocks covered in lush vegetation. I remember how it felt to walk on the soft sand or paddle. How I would love to see and feel those things again now! I feel nostalgic about the adventures we had and events that happened  a Buddhist wedding, elephant trekking, snorkellingto name a few. I am in awe of these memories, and feel very privileged to have seen seen/done these things. Most of all I miss the people I went with, as they live in London so I dont get to see them very often  I do feel a longing to see them again. But I am consoled by memories of amusing events such as drunken antics and encounters with ladyboys (!), which make me laugh to myself and put a smile on my face.

December 2000, I went with another girl to an Outward bound course in South Africa. It involved working as a team of 12 over 2 weeks and we had various tasks and challenges to complete. When I returned from this trip I felt so confident and that I had achieved more than I thought I could have, I met some of the most amazing people I have ever met. I have a longing to be back in South Africa with those people who made me feel so good about myself.

It was my final full day in Mexico, Guadalajaia, Easter 2004, a Thursday. I was in the car with Olivia, who I was staying with, Hannah, her friend and Louis, the oldest brother from the house next door. We were driving to see the new house that Louis family was moving in to. I was so ecstatically happy and so much didnt want to ever go home, I was even hoping we would crash so I wouldnt have. I felt completely and utterly free and 100% myself  true to myself. I was with people who I felt liked me based on only really knowing me for a couple of weeks, which I liked because it meant they liked me exactly as I am now without any preconceptions of me from the past. I felt proud of myself for going there on my own and being spontaneous. Often they were speaking in Spanish and I felt great because I could understand them and join in with their jokes, despite barely being able to speak in Spanish when I arrived. I just felt so complete in every way and so free. I felt the closest to exactly what Ive always wanted to be as I ever had.

I remember sitting in my aunts house. All my mums family were there. My uncle had come over from America with my two young cousins. They were playing in the garden. I sat on the sofa with my Nan. She held my hand. I remember feeling so much love from her so much happiness. This makes me feel nostalgic because I miss her. She has been dead 4 years now. Actually I am not sure maybe 3 years.

Recently I went back to my old secondary school and it made me feel really nostalgic. It made me think of all the times me and my friends would sit in the canteen chatting, or the times that we sat in our form room. It made me feel especially nostalgic as I dont keep in contact with quite a lot of my friends from school and so it made me remember how close we all used to be, and that now we never see or speak to each other which is particularly sad. It made me wonder what they are all up to and I remember how we used to talk about what we would do in the future and its sad to think I dont know if they are fulfilling their wishes and ambitions.

I remember being younger 5-8, when life was so simple and easy, I would play in the garden for hours without complaining. I would never get bored or moan, I was happy to do my own thing. I long to still be in that stage of my life, an innocent child, I long to still be protected like a children, from all the stress of life.

When I was 14 I was very shy and was bullied too for a while. I can sing but never had the bottle to get up and sing in front of people, but I decided to go and sing in school assembly for the first time solo. Everyone was really shocked as I was so quiet at school  I felt really proud of myself, especially as since then Ive had the confidence to sing on many other occasions  if I hadnt got up and done it I may never have done! I feel the adrenaline that I felt as I walked out on stage and heard my intro music, and then remember feeling really happy and proud the more I got through the song, and more confident too. I also saw the faces of people that were mean to me, and that did feel good too, as no-one ever thought Id do something like that, I dont think.

One of my old dogs used to have a mad five minutes every so often, she would run around the lounge and dining room jumping on the furniture and knocking things over. It was really funny to watch and she looked really cute. She died suddenly 4 years ago and I never got to say goodbye. I really miss her and wish I could be back with her again.

Every summer when I was quite young, probably around 5-8 years old, my sister, my cousins and I would spend some of the summer holidays with my grandparents in Windsor. Our parents didnt stay, so we were completely spoiled for a few weeks. We all slept in the main bedroom of their old 3 storey Victorian house. The bedroom took on many disguises, spaceship, castle, car, beach, etc. We would play all day, in the garden, splashing around in red basins, baking chocolate cake with Nana, sitting in my Grandads workshop watching him fix clocks and being startled as all the clocks chimed on the hour. The house was so warm and homely. I can still taste the chocolate cake and vividly remember the cold, damp feel of the workshop. This memory is nostalgic to me as it takes me back to a time of innocence, where the only thing guiding you was your imagination. They were happy memories, but now they upset me a little as I miss having no ties and stresses.

It is my 18th birthday party. Everybody I love is altogether and Im the happiest Ive ever been in my life. I feel so loved. Everyone is praising me and telling me theyre proud. Everyone is having a great time, the weathers great. Everything is perfect. I miss all those people and wish I could see them altogether again. Being at uni makes it difficult, so I havent seen many of them since the party. If I could be anywhere right now, Id be back at my 18th party cherishing every second.

Sitting on the lawn on a Sunday afternoon  in the sun  at home in the garden, with my mum and my best friend. I am candlewicking a picture onto cloth as a present for someone. We are talking and laughing  making fun of me being an old woman with my version of knitting! It makes me feel nostalgic because I do not live in the same country/continent as my mum and my best friend. I miss those times we had to spend casual time together  when it seemed like we had all the time in the world. I miss doing creative crafts  at the same time as hanging out with them. I miss having a family home to spend time in. I feel sad.

Taking care and playing with my baby brother is often something I look back on. The first time we saw him, the first time I was allowed to hold him. Looking at pictures of him when he was little makes me smile. I remember when my mum put him to bed, we all had to come up and say good night, we talk about his day (when he could talk) or just gave him a good night kiss. Looking back on it makes me feel peaceful and proud and happy. Watching someone grow up and looking back on it makes you nostalgic in itself. Just giggles. I remember when he was little we used to dress him up, he loved it and I can still remember his face, giggling. I feel proud of who he is now, seeing someone close to you who was or is happy makes you feel good and puts a smile on your face.

I cannot think of an event specifically that is especially nostalgic for me, but when looking back to the past I suppose that I would love to experience the days where all of my family spend the day with my grandparents. Both of my grandparents on my mums side of the family have passed away and looking back I really miss the days that we used to spend with them; they were so funny! Looking back it makes me feel slightly emotional and certainly experiencing a sentimental longing for the past. However it also fills me with happiness thinking back on it all.

When I was thirteen, I moved from Yorkshire to Southampton and it was a very difficult time. I loved being in Yorkshire and had a great group of friends but when I moved I found it hard to fit in. I was bullied and although not physically, I was very depressed for 2 years. If people tried to invite me to parties, I turned them down and lost many potential friends that way, which I regret. I guess I longed for security in a friendship or a group of friends and my confidence was shattered.

The summer holidays when I lived in Bahrain make me feel nostalgic because it reminds me of when I had no cares in the world. I was about 8 years old and used to go swimming every day and play football in the roasting hot sunshine. The smell of BBQs in the early evening and the relaxed and calm atmosphere bring about the sentimental longing for those days.

At the moment I am feeling most nostalgic about this time last summer when I broke up with my boyfriend. The weather is making me feel more nostalgic. At the time I was very upset so much that I was ill, so things that remind me of that like foods and the weather make my stomach clench up as though I cant eat and feel tearful and stressed for no reason.

The last week of travelling around Australia was spent in Sydney, on my own because my friends had already gone home. I met so many wonderful people, and they all welcomed me and made me feel like I had been there for ages. We went out drinking and the boys tried to teach me to play pool. I went to the zoo and the aquarium and shopping. I was really content there. On my last night there it was my birthday, and I had to leave at 6 in the morning so everybody stayed up with me to see my birthday in, and see me off, and they gave me a mars bar with a candle in it. I felt very touched and special.

On my gap year I went to Ecuador and did a conservation project in the rainforest. We were in the middle of nowhere and we lived in a wooden shack. At the top, on the roof of the shack, there was a hammock. I remember lying in it at night and listening to the sounds of the jungle whilst looking at the amazing view and stars. I always think of this moment because I felt so peaceful and happy. I also felt anticipation about all the amazing things yet to come on my trip. When I think back to this time it makes me feel all these things again but it also makes me feel sad because I am not there and I do not feel those things in my life now, and I haven't got anywhere to get away. It makes me long for that time and get frustrated about my life now. So it makes me feel good and bad things.

I went to America with my boyfriend for 6 weeks last summer. We travelled from the East coast to the West coast of North America. We had a fantastic time, it was the best holiday I have ever had. It makes me feel happy thinking about it. I feel lucky for having the chance to have done something like that. Thinking about it makes me want to go back to that time in my life. It seems as though life was less stressful then, than it is now.

I'm thinking back to lower sixth form. I loved it because every day you'd walk into school and catch up with everyone, even though you'd only seen them the day before. Along the corridors at school, teachers would say hello, or stop and talk to me with a vital message because I was deputy head girl. It made me feel important. At weekends we'd go to the pub and know everyone in there. It was great because it felt so comfortable and you could mingle with hundreds of people. We'd hit the dancefloor and stay there for hours because everyone loved the music. When there was a tune on everyone would react to the music and dance with increased energy and a smile on your face. I was really happy and seemed to have so much energy which I'd direct at activities I liked. I felt like I really belonged in the year and actually played an important role. I was often a mediator between different social groups as I was friends with a lot of them.

About 10 years ago, I went on a family holiday to Spain with my mum and dad and brothers, staying with my grandad in his villa. At that time everything was good  my dad was still with us and more to the point it was hot and we had our own swimming pool. Mum and Dad were very happy and me and the boys could just play. In the evenings we went out for dinner  I got bought loads of dresses to wear! There were no worries back then  only worries over what flavour ice-cream to get, or that my brother got more sweets than me! The family was happy which is why I get nostalgic  now we struggle with our dad. I felt safe, happy and relaxed on this holiday. I am far away from any problems or difficulties that could occur. Nothing can harm me or upset me.

The nostalgia of leaving school. This gives off mixed feelings. There is definitely the nostalgia of still wanting to be there. It was easy and you knew everyone. There is the longing to still be there with all my friends and with everyone that I knew. It makes me happy thinking of all the good times I had there and makes me sad thinking of all the people I knew from school that Ill never see again and many others that Ill slowly lose touch with. Being there was secure and happy and feelings that something has been lost come about. School was filled with so many mixed emotions but when thinking back it is only the happy memories that stand out to me. It makes me miss seeing all my friends I became so close to and the routine of everyday. I always think though of how things can never last forever and so just look on it as a good experience of my past although I often become nostalgic about it all.

I long for those family holidays together where all my family were there as well as friends, which simply doesnt happen any more because of time. I miss those holidays, yet remember the happiness of them that makes me smile. I realise the love I have for my family.

The nostalgic feeling occurred when I was travelling around Europe, during the summer that just passed. We were travelling down from Vienna, en route to Croatia, however due to a muddle up with the trains and connecting trains, we ended up in Lubjiana (Slovenia) at 8:15pm. Looking at the board we realized that there was a train going to Rula in Croatia at 10:15pm  so we decided to get that train. However, at 9:45pm, we came back to the train station after finding some food with the last of Slovenian money we had, and beyond there was no train going anywhere near Croatia until 3:30am (6/7 hours later). We had looked at the arrivals part of the board instead of the departures. For the next 6 hours, my friend and I roughed it in the subway part of the station. I felt so cold, and homeless and very homesick. I longed for my own bed, in England whilst we were in some train station pretty much in the middle of nowhere as we had no money, didnt really know where we were exactly and could not speak the language.

Have just broken up with long term boyfriend of 4 years. Thinking of past events makes me feel nostalgic  makes me want to go back to how it was then. Especially holidays and good times spent together. Meals, on holidays and days out together. Christmases together sitting with the family watching TV. All of these make me feel happy but then very sad that this time has gone. Want to go back to this time. Makes me feel angry cos remember why we split up. Would rather not think of these nostalgic times. Want to push them out of my mind so they dont upset me.

Being in Connaught Halls of Residence. This makes me nostalgic as I had such an amazing time in halls with everyone and made some true lasting friends that its sad we arent all living under the same roof any more. Obviously you still see people around but not on an everyday basis like we did going to breakfast, and dinner. The All day event in the last week of the summer term brings back good memories the sun was out, everyone was laughing, drinking, having fun and exams were over. Not a worry in the world. I feel sad as I know I will never be in a situation quite like that again, but it wouldnt be the same if you went back now anyway.

I think about my leavers ball at the end of sixth form. Being surrounded by all my closest friends dressed in beautiful dresses and suits. I feel warm when I think about it. I feel sad that that night will never happen again and my relationships with those people are now different. I smile when I think of us all laughing and flirting and drinking too much. I feel happy knowing how happy I was that evening and now nothing could take that away. I feel bad when I think of the people Ive lost contact with but I smile when I think of them and how we all shared that evening. I find myself grinning as I remember the girls huddling in the toilets discussing the boys but then I feel upset that we no longer huddle in those groups.

When I competed in the Commonwealth Games last year, it was my best performance in athletics and I had a fantastic experience. It was such an amazing event and with the home crowd in Manchester, it was such a high feeling while I was running. This past experience makes me feel very proud of my performance and gives me a lot of inspiration and motivation in my training. It almost gives me butterflies just thinking about it. I also wish sometimes that another event in Britain could be staged here, as it was so a great atmosphere to be part of.

Going on holiday with my 2 best friends to Feurteventura when I was 16. We had so much fun and got on so well. I felt so content and so happy, I didnt want it to end. It was just after exams so we had been working hard and were stressed out. It was good to feel the stress and worry of exams disappear. I felt very content as I knew I had a long summer ahead of me with nothing to worry about. I feel like I would like to be there again with my friends and no worries, as I miss my friends.

When I was younger, on my birthdays we always used to go around to my Grannys house and she used to make me birthday tea. She would always go to a lot of effort and my mum would always bring along a birthday cake she had made. My granny was so intelligent and witty that the conversations used to make me laugh and laugh. My brother who is two years older was always there and my Dad would arrive later after work. In that situation I used to feel so comfortable and secure with all my family around me. Unfortunately now my Granny is 93 and in a home. She is bed bound due to the amount of shakes she has and her memorys no longer with her. I often wish that I could go back to the times when she was fit and healthy and she made me feel like a little princess. It saddens me to see her the way she is now. I think I didnt appreciate her enough when I had the chance.

The first time I went foxhunting I was 12 and riding a small hairy pony called Twiggy. The day was misty, grey and damp, the air smelled wonderful  damp leaves, earth, hot horses. People were all very friendly, even when Twiggy and I took off past the rest of the field and involuntarily caught up with the huntsman  I didnt have an awful lot of control. The day was great fun and I suppose Im nostalgic for the chance to hunt again, or even to ride as much as Id like. Hunting could soon be a thing of the past, which makes me feel sad and then angry. Perhaps it also stands for a way of life that Im not really involved in any more and part of me regrets that.

Years ago, a holiday in Wales with my family. Playing with my brother on the beach  trying to build a dam to make a lagoon, and making a boat out of sand, and me falling into the lagoon and having to walk back in my brothers t-shirt. Seeing photos brings back the memory, of that event and generally of holidays in Wales. Brings back times when me and my brother had a lot of fun, him being older and slightly ordering me, slightly looking after me. Thinking about it makes me wish we could be young and silly again, and also go on a family holiday again.

Going to Paris with my parents and sister. This makes me feel nostalgic because it was the last proper holiday we had together before my father died. It makes me feel happy to think about it because it was a lot of fun spending one long weekend abroad but it also make me feel sad that I cant have that experience again with the same people. It does make me have a longing for the past and things I might have done differently.

Approximately 8 years ago, I visited India. It was the most amazing three weeks of my life. We went for Christmas, so stayed the week of Christmas in a resort but travelled around for the other two weeks of our stay. It was such an experience, I learnt so much about their culture, saw beautiful things did so many things that wouldnt have been possible anywhere else. All my family were together at this point. This is also probably why it is particularly significant. This is because my parents have split up and my older brother and sister have both moved out of home and are working abroad. It was a rare space of time in which we all stayed together and experienced such amazing things.

The experience that makes me most feel nostalgic is the summer holidays at primary school, when I would play outside on the river bank which is at the bottom of my garden, and in the forest close to my home. We would build dens in the forest and make up stories around them and act them out. We would build bridges across the river and pretend to charge each other a fee to cross. The reason these summers make me feel nostalgic is that I was very happy and carefree, I had nothing at all to worry about except what time I had to be home for dinner. I had lots of fun with my friends and the 6 weeks seem to last forever, and the summer seemed hotter and sunnier. This is in contrast to how I feel now, time seems to go too fast!

The feelings of falling in love with my ex-boyfriend for the first time  the happy memories that left me feeling content. The way we used to go to places together and hed pick me up and carry me through public places. When he used to come to my house for family occasions  hed love it as he has no real family of his own. Id love giving him what he couldnt have with anyone or anywhere else. I always wanted to make him feel special. I love the way he used to get in a really silly, playful mood on a Sunday afternoon when I got back from work  I wish I had cherished those moments more (no-one feels like doing anything after work). When we used to go out and get drunk and then hed tell me how special I was to him, with silly conversations about marriage and the future. He loved me very much and I loved him.

When I was younger we went on a family holiday, me my mum my two brothers and my dad, who no longer lives with us. This holiday was the last true whole family holiday. Thinking of this holiday makes me feel happy because we had such a good time, making sandcastles and going to restaurants all together, laughing and playing about in the sea. Then I feel resentful because things have changed and slightly angry that he is no longer there. But the happy feelings outweigh the unhappy. I can picture the experience very clearly and it makes me feel all warm and slightly emotional looking back.

The memory of travelling in Europe with my boyfriend makes me feel nostalgic because I was spending time with the person I love and we had nothing we had to do or anywhere we had to be. We were free to go where we wanted, make last minute decisions and not have anything to worry about. The weather was lovely, we got to talk a lot. Made me realise that he is my best friend as well as my boyfriend. Thinking about it makes me feel warm and happy. It makes me laugh thinking about some moments. Makes me want to do it all again.

The night before leaving for university my 6 best friends and I went to a mutual friends house to say goodbye. It was very emotional and everyone cried a lot. We had spent much time at that particular friends house so it held a lot of memories for all of us. At the end of the evening we realized that we only had 10 minutes until the taxi would arrive and we would all go our separate ways. I felt almost desperate not to say goodbye and when the taxi arrived we were all nearly hysterical. As my friends left the house we all hugged goodbye and I really didnt want them to leave as they all felt like family. As the taxi pulled away and my friends waved out of the windows crying I felt quite scared but not alone as I knew we would still keep contact. At the same time I was a little excited at the prospect of going to uni and excited for them as I knew they were all looking forward to it as well although I would miss them very much.

Meeting my boyfriend for the first time 3 years ago. It had so many good feelings you only experience when you dont know someone and you are full of anticipation. You are constantly longing to be with that person over the first few meetings  looking back makes you feel happy, almost relive the butterflies and excitement. I feel very content and sentimental when thinking about specific aspects of the event i.e., where we met, where we went out, what the occasion was etc. I remember quite specific things that happened or that were said.

I had an amazing Christmas and New Year in New Zealand when I took a gap year. I felt completely free of responsibilities and had no worries. I was surrounded by good friends who made me feel comfortable, relaxed, happy and whom I could be myself around. We never laughed so much. We had so much fun, playing games and drinking. I would love to relive that week, just to be carefree and happy, truly at ease and to feel as though there is nothing bad in the world.

A nostalgic event that has personal meaning is when my dad went missing. He had left a note that said he could not cope any more and was leaving. I can still remember vividly that day when I found the note, it was numbness all over me. I felt so worried and so sad. I just kept reflecting back on the happy times that we had even just the normal things like dad laughing in the chair, I just wanted to see that again so I could feel happy and safe. All that day that dad went missing and the police were round, I just kept thinking it was not true, I just wanted to see dad in his chair and it was hurtful that this was not happening. Even when dad was found and brought home it still was not the same and it felt very weird. I just wanted to see dad smile again.

I left the house pulling the door firmly shut and I walked up the path. Turning left I headed up the pavement until I came to an alley. Turning left down it I walked down the steps listening to my music the whole way. Turning right at the alley I walked past the engineering block and arrived at the library. Turning off my walkman I went in.

My alarm woke me up at 7.30. I showered, got changed and did hair and make-up. Breakfast time! All Bran and Bran Flakes and a cuppa. Walked in to uni for a 9 oclock lec. Very boring stuff. Went to the computer room, checked emails and did some work. Another lecture, stats  so hard! Walked home, picked up some skimmed milk on the way. Chilled out, put a CD on, read my bible and a mag. Had some tea, pasta, tuna and olives in tomato sauce. Put on my work uniform  waitress at pizza and pasta house. Drove in and worked a 7-hour shift  very tiring. Came home, showered, rung boyfriend. Bed at about 12.30/1.00.

On Saturday morning I woke up with the usual hangover, trying to force myself back to sleep. When I couldnt sleep I went into my housemates room and watched Sex and the City, which had been recorded from Friday night. Then I got up and had some toast and tried to decide whether or not to go home that night. I rang a few friends and arranged that I would. So I got on the U1 bus and went to the train station. My friend and her mum picked me up at the other end.

Last Tuesday I had to be in University for a group practical meeting at 11.55. We had previously booked a room in which to watch a video of a child in Ainsworths Strange Situation. My boyfriend was at my house because he had stayed the night before. He was irritated that I had to leave early, but I did not want to be late. We had only booked the room for an hour and this was cutting it fine. I walked to the bus stop, and saw a bus just pull away from the bus stop as I turned the corner. I ran as fast as I could to the next bus stop and manage to catch as it was about to pull away. I banged on the door, and asked the driver if he was a number 6. He said he was an 8. So I waited at this bus stop for a further 45 minutes. No bus turned up. I thought maybe it had been diverted so went up a small road that buses are often diverted up. A number 20 turned up about five minutes later. I got on paid 1.20 and had to run the last mile or two to the university, because this bus stopped further away. I met the rest of the girls in the Shackleton Building on time.

At around 12.50 today, I finished taking part in an experiment and went to buy a baguette from the union caf, as I was hungry. I left the Shackleton building and walked up the hill to the union, as I dont like the steps! There were lots of people around, walking and chatting and the union was very busy, probably due to it being lunch-time. I went to the baguette counter and asked for a bacon, lettuce and tomato baguette from the moody woman who was serving. I then left and tried eating the baguette as I walked home, but lots of filling kept falling out on the way, so I put it in my bag so I could eat it at home instead. I waited at the traffic lights with a group of people but then remembered I had to buy a stamp from the Post Office.  I went and bought a stamp, a Chinese man served me, then I went home.

I locked the front door, walked up to my car and got in, I turned on the engine and put a CD on. I started to drive to university and parked up about 30 minutes walk away. I waited for my friend to arrive and walked into uni with her. I arrived to my lecture on time.

I went into town with a girl called Amy. She gave me a lift in in her car. When we got to town we parked the car in a free car park and walked through John Lewis to get into West Quay. We rang her housemates (on her mobile) to see where they were and went to meet them in Topshop. Amys housemates picked out some underwear for their other housemates birthday. They paid for the items and then we went into Clinton Cards. Once they had chosen their cards, they gave their money to Amy and left her to pay. They went home. Amy and I then paid for the cards and looked around a shoe shop. Having found nothing we walked through Marlands to Asda. I bought 5 frozen meals, paid for them and then we returned to Amys car. She then drove me home through Portswood and dropped me outside my house.

I went to the pub on Wednesday evening. I picked my friends Nadine and Andy up and we drove to our local, called the Shamblehurst Barn. We had a meal downstairs in the restaurant at 7.30. I ate chicken fajitas. Then we all shared a dessert. At around 9.00pm we went upstairs and stayed there til 10.00pm drinking. Then at 10, I drove my friends home.

I woke up this morning to go to my 9.00 lecture on Psychology and health. After this I walked over to the local convenience store to collect some essentials I needed, for example bread and milk. I walked back home  Glen Eyre Halls, down Glen Eyre Rd. Here, I bumped into a friend on his bike. I stopped and chatted with him and then carried on with my journey home. Once I was home I made myself something to eat  cereal, and checked my e-mails. After being at home for about 2 hours it was time to go back to university for another lecture.

Ciara Wiltshire and Mike Sullivan going to get a MacDonalds. Left Mikes house at approximately five oclock. Drove to MacDonalds in Swaythling. Ciara ordered a super size fries and chocolate milkshake. Mike ordered a chicken nugget meal with Coke. Sat in the car in the car park to eat it (ordered the meal at a drive through) and then drove home.

I went to Sholing school. On the way my mum phoned me and we spoke for 10 mins. At school I dealt with the girls and helped them with their practicals. After school was over I walked for 15 mins to the post office. Here I purchased stamps for my mums mothers day card and my sister birthday card. Then I got the train to St Denys Station at 15.14. When I got home I realised that I had left my book at the post office. As there was only one train an hour my friend gave me a lift. I collected my books then went home and did some work.

Drove to work. Took car out of garage. Closed garage door down. Got in car. Indicated to go left. Drove out of drive. Drove down road to mini roundabout. Drove up main road to work. Stopped at several traffic lights. Reached work car park. Bought parking ticket. Put it on windscreen inside car. Locked car and walked to work.

I woke up at 7.30am when my alarm went off. I spoke briefly to my boyfriend on the phone, then got dressed and went downstairs. I switched on the kettle, made a cup of tea and lit a cigarette. Having smoked my cigarette and drank my tea, I ate a bowl of cereal and collected my bag, before leaving the house to walk to university.

At 0600 I turned up to work on my day off Uni. At 0615 I went to load my truck with cars opened the back of the truck, took out the ramps and prepared the straps. I went to find the car, was given paperwork for a car and went to get the keys. I then found the car  a Toyota MR2 Roadster. The car was driven into the truck, strapped down and locked. I then drove the truck to somebodys house to deliver it.

On Saturday morning after breakfast I drove to Winchester to go shopping. It was raining when I left, but sunny as I pulled up at the park and ride. After paying for a ticket I got on the bus to the centre of Winchester. I looked round all the mobile phone shops and spent ages in Waterstones trying to find a highway code. When I found it I looked up what the white circles in the M3 were. Then I got back on the bus to the park and ride and then drove home.

On Saturday 9th May, twelve men from Montefiore Halls, Southampton, lined up against twelve foreign students in a friendly football match arranged a few minutes prior outside the halls reception. The foreign students were significantly older, and the majority were of Greek origin. The match began at quite a frantic pace, with the men from Montefiore finding it difficult to maintain their level of play due to poor fitness levels. The foreign students scored first, with a Spanish man called Manu claiming the goal. Despite numerous chances, and a few successful runs by the more talented Montefiore players, the strength and fitness of the foreign students was enough to undermine the lethargic Montefiore teams attempts to get back into the game. The match ended four goals to one, with Montefiore scoring late in the match, but it was little more than a consolation goal.

It was Thursday and I had no lectures that day and I was bored. However we had arranged to go out that night. Me and my friends caught the U1 bus at 9.00 and arrived at Academy at 9.20. I went straight to the bar and asked for some wine but they didnt have any so I got a vodka red devil. Then Carla walked and came up and spoke to me, but I couldnt think of anything to say so there was an awkward silence. Later that night she was talking to someone else.

I had to go to University for an experiment, I got up and got ready whilst watching fragments of television. The time came when I had to leave the house and get in my car to drive to university, but I couldnt find my keys. I searched in all the normal places, and still couldnt find them. I contemplated phoning my boyfriend to see if he knew where they might be. After a couple of minutes of searching I found them under a jumper on the couch. Then I got in the car and went to university.

I arrived at work at 6.30  and waited outside for my boss to arrive as I had forgotten the door code. I was on DM training so my boss showed me how to unlock the bar, deactivate the alarm and sort the tills. Sarah and Jo arrived at 7 to set up the tables and take the pool table outside. We had to move the pool table under the shade as it rained. The DJ turned up around 8.30, but didnt start til 9. The bar was relatively empty til 11  but we still stayed open til 1.

The alarm went off at 8.15am. I got out of bed, turned the light on, got dressed in jeans, a blue t-shirt, socks. Put my shoes on. Ate breakfast of crunchy nut cornflakes with milk and drank orange juice. I picked up my bag with my keys in it, locked my door and met up with a friend and walked down to campus. We walked in to the Lanchester building for our lecture and sat down in the lecture theatre. Waited for the lecture to start. After the lecture we went to the campus library.

The alarm went off at 6.45. Dan knocked twice to get me up and we were off. I didnt bring a jumper so I was cold cycling this early but the pool is only 5 minutes away. We are changed and in the pool by 7.15, I do 10 laps while Dan is in the fast lane. Then he teaches me front crawl and I am nearly sick from swallowing too much water.

I open the kitchen door and walked in. I walked to the freezer and took out a box of spring rolls. I read the instructions and turned on the oven. I opened the fridge and took out a bag of mushrooms and a carrot. I took a few mushrooms out of the bag and washed them. I then peeled the carrot and got out my chopping board. I began to chop the mushrooms and the carrot. I put a little oil in a saucepan and heated it up then put the carrot and mushrooms in the saucepan. The oven was now hot enough so I put in two spring rolls, on a tray. I stirred the vegetables and let them cook. When everything was cooked I put it on a plate and took it to my room to eat.

My girlfriend visited on the weekend. We met at around 5pm. The arrangement was supposed to be at my house however she picked me up from the gym as I finished late. The length of time spent getting ready was not as long as usual. The decision to occupy our time came with more ease than usual due to the good weather. A pub lunch in a beer garden was satisfactory to both of us. We arrive at one place to find out food was no longer being served. The next place we stumbled on was amazing. The day was over very quickly.

I got on the number 66 bus into the city centre. I sat on the bus, listening to my CD walkman. I got off the bus when it arrived at the high street. I walked up the street and went into Woolworths to buy a birthday card. I came out of the shop and went into the precinct. I went into a few more shops and bought a black top. I went to Marks and Spencer to buy a sandwich. I left the precinct and went back to the bus stop. I waited for the 66 bus to arrive and then got on and went back home.

I went shopping yesterday. I travelled to the shops by bus. I went on the U6C at about 2 o'clock. I was shopping for Christmas and birthday presents. I got out 50 pounds from the Lloyds TSB cashpoint. I looked around many shops. I went into West Quay, Marlands and Bargate. I bought a Shakeaway milkshake in chocolate fudge brownie flavour, some make-up and some batteries among other things. I put some money in a Children in Need collector's bucket. I went alone. I got the U6H bus back home at approx. 5:30pm. I showed my housemates what I had bought. I wrapped a birthday present and wrote a birthday card.

At 8.05 she left her house, walked along Milton Road, stopping halfway to post her letter. At 8.12 her friends met her and they proceeded to walk to university. The traffic was heavy. The girls waited a long time at each set of traffic lights they passed as a result. The U1 and U2 buses passed them as they negotiated getting on, so the walk continued. At 8.50 they arrive at the Highfield campus. They enter the back entrance of the Shackleton building and proceed to Room 3095.

I left the house and walked to the bus stop. I got on a U6 bus into town. I got off the bus and walked to the shops. I spent some time looking around the shops. I saw my friend in town and spoke for a while. I looked round the shops for a while longer. I went back up to the bus stop and caught a U6 bus home.

Got a lift to Tescos with a housemate. The housemate sat in the car as I shopped. I had to spend more than 25 in order to get 25 off a new phone as old one was lost. Chose some vegetables first. Then moved on around the shop finding all the other things I needed. Once had got everything went back to the phones and spent quite a long time choosing. When I returned to my trolley a little girl was climbing on it and almost pulled it on top of herself, but managed to catch it first. Then went to the checkout, as putting everything on the conveyer belt put a few things back. Paid. Went to customer services and got the phone, went back to the car and went home.

I had a lecture on Monday morning at 9am. It was titled Why bother to learn. It was part of the Biology behaviour and learning lectures. I woke up at 7.30, had breakfast and got ready. Met Vicki and Rachel and walked from Glen Eyre to the Engineering building where the lecture took place. I met Sam on the way also. The lecturer was Bob Remington. He discussed the video that we watched in Fridays lecture about animal learning. The lecture went on for 45 minutes. Then I walked back to Glen Eyre Halls with Vicki and Rachel. It was cold and raining.

I left my front door, travelled down the road and arrived outside Safeway. I walked through the entrance doors. They were automatic. I picked up a basket, and walked down each aisle seeing what there was to buy. Once I had finished, I took all my goods to the check-out and paid with my Switch card. I placed all I had bought into bags and walked through the exit doors. I then reversed my journey home and entered back through my front door.

I left the house at 7pm, got in my car and drove for approx. 15 minutes to get to my friend Lauras house. I pulled up in the driveway and turned my car lights off and it was very dark. I managed to find the gate but at first couldnt undo it. Finally, I managed, walked through it, stepped over puddles and knocked on her door. Laura opened it and we hugged, we had not seen each other for 2+ years.

At approximately 6.00pm on Thursday 27th November 2003 I decided to make my evening meal. I went into the kitchen and opened my cupboard, I took out some garlic, an onion and a bag of pasta. I took a fillet of chicken out of the fridge and chopped it into small pieces then placed them into a frying pan on the hob. I diced the onion and garlic and put them in with the chicken. I boiled the kettle, then poured the water over some pasta that I had placed in a saucepan on the hob. I then stir-fried the chicken while the pasta was cooking. I out the chicken in with the pasta and stirred-in a tomato and basil sauce. I served this on a plate with some salad and then grated some cheese over the top. I had finished cooking, so I sat in the lounge and ate with the rest of my housemates while watching Hollyoaks.

On Tuesday evening once I had finished my University studies, I got in my car at 3.30pm and drove to pick up my friend who lives just round the road. I picked her up and drove to the cinema in Leisureworld in Southampton. We parked the car and walked into the cinema and bought two tickets to see the film, Love Actually. We bought some soft drinks and popcorn and went through to Screen 12, which was showing the film we went to see. We watched the adverts and trailers, followed by the film and then went out to the car and I drove my friend home and then went home myself.

My parents arrived at 1.00pm, while I was working. We left my house and got in their car. We drove to a local pub and waited for a table. We chose three different meals: gammon, pork and mash and fish and potatoes. We finished and went shopping in town. I bought a new blue jumper. My mother bought some Christmas presents for our family. We then got in the car and drove home. My parents came in for a cup of tea and a chat. They left at 7pm and I went back to work.

I went to work on Saturday. I woke up at 7.00am in the morning and got ready. My mum drove me to work and when I got there I swiped in with my employee card. I then put my belongings in a locker and went to the kitchen. I put my apron and hat on and began work. Firstly, I cooked off 40 baguettes in the oven for 10 minutes. Then I prepared the sandwich fillings. Then I buttered 60 pieces of bread and the baguettes. I then made all of the sandwiches and put them in the fridge. I then cleared up and remade all of the sandwich fillings. Then I helped the other chefs prepare a buffet for a wedding. At 4 oclock, I went home.

I got up at 7.30, went downstairs and had a drink and a piece of toast, went upstairs, got washed and dressed and packed my bag for lectures. Left the house at 8.20, walked down the road to meet my friend who I walk to lectures with. Arrived at university at 9ish and go to my first lecture. Sit down and wait for the lecture to start.

It was 5.00 and I was waiting for the bus as I usually do every Friday afternoon. As usual, the bus was running a few minutes late. After a further five minutes the bus arrived. I paid my 1.40 to the bus driver and took my place on a seat towards the back of the bus. I then immediately reached into my bag to pull out my portable CD player. Traffic was building up and the bus seemed to stop every few minutes to let people off. After almost 45 minutes journey time and nearly 12 songs later I finally arrived at work. Once at work I went straight upstairs to change into my uniform. I still had a few minutes to spare before starting so I made myself a cup of tea. I decided to take this downstairs and drink it while talking to the other staff about our respective weeks. It was now 6.00pm and my shift had begun. There were already many customers so I expected it to be a busy Friday night.

Steph woke up at 7.30am. She got out of bed and walked into the bathroom. She showered and brushed her teeth, and went back into her bedroom. She chose her clothes to wear, got dressed and went downstairs. She had toast and tea for breakfast, returned upstairs to collect her bag, put on her shoes and make-up and set off for university. She walked to her friends house and knocked on the door. Her friend answered the door and they both went inside. She sat in her friends room whilst her friend finished getting ready and they both walked to university. They walked up the stairs of the Shackleton building and entered room 3095 for their first lecture.

On Wednesday, went into town instead of doing uni work. Caught the bus from the bus stop opposite Safeway in Portswood  the U6C at 12.38. Arrived in town, and as normal went round all the shops first without buying anything. Meet friend for lunch, then went back round all the shops again and spent loads of money havent got. Bought jeans, 2 tops, CD album, pair of shoes and lunch. Got home quite late after doing Asda shopping  caught the U6C back to Portswood. Instead of doing some work  proceeded to try my new clothes on and then watch TV with my housemates.

After hitting the snooze button on her alarm clock, the girl finally stumbled out of bed. The clock read 7.50 and after rushing around for a few seconds, the girl grabbed a towel, and some shower wash and dashed to the shower. 5 minutes later she returned to her room, took a quick glance in her wardrobe and seemed to grab the closest thing to hand. Once dressed, she headed to the kitchen greeting a few equally happy people along the way. She prepared a glass of orange squash, and a bowl of bran flakes with skimmed milk. It didnt take her long to polish off the breakfast, wash up her plate, glass and spoon, take her sandwiches out of the fridge and head back to her room. Here she fiddled about with her hair for a few minutes, brushed her teeth and put some mascara on. There was a knock on the door at 8.27 and the girl shouted, Hang on, just looking for my keys. She rushed around, muttering to herself, finding her keys on the bedside table. Pulling her jacket on and hurling her heavy bag over her shoulder she pulled the door to, locked it and headed down the stairs.

Event - Going to Chicagos  getting ready to go out. Had a shower whilst everyone was watching Neighbours in the room next door to me. After showering, I went in to my room, moisturised etc. then had to decide what to wear. Rang friend down corridor to ask what she was wearing  she came into my room to decide. Got dressed, had a drink whilst getting dressed, music on in background and TV but not really watching it. Started doing make-up, then hair. Go and see what everyone else is wearing and chat to them. Book taxis, quickly pack bag. Run to taxis, get dropped off at Chicagos.

I walked into university and met my practical psychology group. We each entered the data that we had collected in SPSS. I then took a disk from each person and saved the data. I also emailed the data to each member of the group in the event that the data was not saved correctly. We found that this was the case and that half the data had been lost. While the other members of the group went to a lecture on human memory, I remained in the Undergraduate Network Room and entered the data a second time, and saved it onto disk.

Myself and two close friends went to the cinema to watch a film. We walked into the screen and found our seats in the dark. A slightly annoyed look passes my face as I see that we are seated near the front and the cinema is very full. I sit down and chat with my friends just as the adverts come on. My eyes are sparkly and shining as the film previews looked good. The film starts. The atmosphere changes. Tension builds. Suddenly the guy seated next to me starts to open a bag of something, making a racket in the process. I am slightly emotional and hyper aware of sound and therefore angry at man next to me. Ignore him and return to viewing. My reactions to the film vary in emotion, and I become tense and wound up as the film reaches its end. The end comes and I feel an emotional wreck. I chatter with my friends. I loosen up. I leave the cinema content.

At 11.30am they arrived after calling on the mobile phone to explain why they were late. Resting followed before the three people, a mother and two daughters went out into the car. They drove into the centre of town for approximately 20 minutes before parking and leaving the vehicle. The 3 people then went to look at the shops within the area of West Quay shopping centre. They sat down and had lunch  sausage sandwich, at 1.45pm before continuing their trip shopping. No one else bought any items, simply looked at the shops which were in the area. They then returned to their car and drove back to Wessex Lane and went inside.

I got up at 9.00am, rang my flatmate to wake him up, he didnt hear so I knocked on his door and he answered. We walked to his car and he gave me a lift to my job in West Quay shopping centre. There was no traffic, so I was early. I sat around until it was time to be at work. I then went upstairs, changed into my uniform, came down, clocked in and was told where Id be working that day. I served customers all day. At 5.00pm my shift ended and I clocked out, talked to my manager about swapping hours and walked back to the civic centre to catch the U2 bus back. I ended up getting on the U1. I then walked back to my flat. I arrived home about 6.30pm.

At 6.00pm I picked my boyfriend up from work. We drove home and had dinner. At 6.45 I went and had a bath and started to get ready to go out. I chose my outfit got dressed and did my hair and make-up. We both had a couple of drinks. At 8.00pm we got a lift into the city centre. We went to the pub and met with friends. There we stayed for a few drinks and then moved on to another pub. At the end of the night we got a taxi home and got to bed at 2.30am.

It was Thursday evening, I was at home. I was bored so said to two of my housemates would you like to go to Sobar (pub) tonight. They did want to go, so we got our shoes on and walked down to the pub. The walk took about 20 minutes and it was cold. When we got to the pub it was warm. We bought drinks and looked around for somewhere to sit. Seeing friends at a table in the corner we went to sit with them. We stayed just over two hours, until closing time. We then walked back to our house. It was still cold.

I got on the U2 bus to go into town. I arrived in town, got off the bus and walked down the high-street. When I reached West Quay I walked in and went into Warehouse first where I returned an item of clothing that I had changed my mind about. I then went into various other shops, not looking for anything in particular. I bought a bag. I then went to Asda to buy some food. Following this I walked to the bus stop and waited for the U2 bus. It was late, but I eventually got on the bus and returned home.

Last Wednesday, I went out in the evening to Ikon and Diva nightclub. I went with five other people; two of them my housemates, Mark and Ed, and three of them my friends from home who were visiting; Laura, Nicki and Tom. We got two taxis to take us there. One arrived at 9.00 which myself, Ed and Mark went in, and one arrived at 9.05 which the others went in. it took us about 10 minutes to get there. On arrival, we got cash from the cashpoint. We then went to Jaks bar for one and a half hours and drank about 5 drinks each. We queued up at the express door for entry into Diva. Queuing took 20 minutes. Once in, we put our coats into the cloakroom  there was no queue there, then got two each at the bar. After drinking these, we danced in Ikon for about half an hour, and got more drinks. This cycle continued until 1.40 when we decided to leave. Queued up at the cloakroom for 10 minutes, then got taxis home, arriving at about 2.05am.

I remember being about 8 years old when we were living in Germany where our bedroom had marble window ledges.  I shared the bedroom with my younger brother and my parents were having a party downstairs and we had been sent to bed at the usual time but we couldnt sleep because it was too noisy and we could sit on the window ledge and watch people arriving.  It made me feel very excited and important as all the guests were coming to our house.

On the day I retired I was already feeling emotional after a lifetimes work.  On top of this I took delivery of an 8 week old black Labrador puppy who has since become my shadow.  I spend more time with the dog than I do with any of my family.

I was very fond of father and can always remember the last five years of his life more so as he partially lost his speech and use of his limbs due to a stroke.  His death was a real shock to me as I witnessed it.  The burial was also very emotional and painful seeing him being laid in the grave.  I took his loss so badly and was grieving for a long time.  Even now after almost 10 years every time I remember it, I feel very emotional and sad.

I was part of the crew who took a Concorde charter to Egypt to visit the pyramids.  We flew supersonic both ways for a short period of time to give the passengers the experience of Mach 1.  I remember being amazed when we left the hotel to visit the pyramids just how close they were to the city.  The crew stayed together and all rode on a camel, then the best part of the trip the tour around and inside the huge pyramids.  I felt in awe that these enormous structures had been constructed without modern machinery and tried to imagine the lives of the people involved with building all those years ago.  I remember feeling slightly claustrophobic when we climbed the path inside to a chamber, again trying to think of the people who had trod this way thousands of years before.  Felt very privileged to have visited and also a very small part of this amazing world.

During my childhood, growing up in North London, there were always plenty of amusements that we could enjoy free of charge and without and constrains of Health and Safety.  An abundance of war damaged buildings and areas scarred with craters that we could all enjoy playing in on our way home from school.  As we proceeded home from school, along the Edgware Road, there was an excellent slide on one such crater.  We would take it in turns to launch ourselves down in a pram without wheels.  On Saturdays it would be Flicks in the morning for couple of hours for sixpence in old money.  Once pence for half a packet of polo mints and maybe a visit to the fish and chip shop for a one penny bag of crackling (all the old bits of batter that had fallen off the fish) and hope to get a couple of chips thrown in.  There were trips to the railway sidings at West Hendon and walking between the steam trains in the goods yard.  We also had the advantage of the Police Training College and the Hendon Airfield all of which we seemed to access without problems.  We all had a good time free from any worries or fears.

On visits to my grandparents in Scotland during the summer holidays I used to go on regular walks along the farm road.  I was aged about ten or eleven and would take a neighbours baby on the walks in her pram.  I loved doing this and it made me feel grown up.  I would get up and patiently wait for the neighbours curtains to be opened so I could collect her for a walk.  The farm road had dry stone walls, telegraph wires and cows grazing.  I remember the wind in the telegraph wires.  I felt very happy.

Every school summer holiday my mum, me and my 2 sisters would visit my Nan in Berkhampsted, we would stay a week.  To get there we had to get 2 buses and an Intercity train! While we were there we would spend hours (if it was sunny) playing in the back garden.  There were 2 sheds which had a big gap around them with quite a big drop, the house was on a hill which meant the garden sloped down.  We would play chase with our Uncle and hide-and-seek around them and would always be told to be careful, we never did take much notice.  She also had an outside toilet which was pretty scary in the dark.

Giving birth to my son, my first child.  Was a bit traumatic as he was 5 days late and was going to be a Caesarean.  Felt a bit odd when people were asking me when he was going to be born and I could give them a time, as well as date.  Remember feeling nervous but wanting to get him here safely.  Very scared about them starting epidural before my husband was there.  Afterwards I felt exhausted, relieved and very happy.  So much so I didnt feel the stitches.

I was married 60 years ago, our wedding day was very nostalgic so simple but a very happy occasion.  The reception was in my parents little front room.  Money was very short in those days, but we had saved enough to have a honeymoon in a small hotel in Buckinghamshire.  Not many people could afford cars in those days, so we had to travel by train to get there.  On returning home which was with my parents in Margate we had just one penny left between us, well until our next pay day.  My husband made a hole in this penny, and has carried it on his key ring ever since.  It is now so thin and shiny, but it has so many nostalgic memories and people love hearing the story.

All my life I have enjoyed watching and riding on the chain ferry at the entrance to Poole Harbour.  It brings back happy memories of my childhood and being with my family.  It is still mildly exciting and I get the feeling that it is build with good solid, strong , old fashioned engineering.

Every Christmas Eve my very English father kept his promise to my very welsh mother as he drove our family of five to Swansea.  My favourite Aunt and Uncle greeted our sleepy family with hugs and kisses and welcomed us into their cosy kitchen warmed by a raging aga.  The next day the house filled with merry chaos of up to forty feasting relatives.  Afterwards aunts clattered and chattered in the kitchen, uncles with brandy exchanged stories whilst 12 giggling cousins chases and skidded around the polished tiled floor in the hall.  As dusk fell the whole ensemble crowded into the huge lounge in front of a glowing fire.  All fell silent as a faint tinkling of bells could be heard.  Twelve wide-eyed cousins watched as Santa stomped; boots, sack and presents into the room.  The experience was magical, treasured and never forgotten, including a sense of belonging.

I remember being taken by my father to a beach which was just ten minutes away from our house.  There he taught my sisters and myself how to body dive in the waves.  It was a very sandy beach and sand collected in our swimming suits as we swam.  It was a very happy time spent with my father; who otherwise would have been at work.

A camping holiday by the sea with friends.  We are all having a fantastic time, fishing and swimming. We are very relaxed and enjoying each others company, cooking and eating together.  Talking and telling jokes until the earlier hours of the morning in pleasant company. Everyone is happy not a moment of sadness, no arguments.  Playing games and taking long walks in the wet sand.  A great sense of adventure and wishing it not to end.

I am very nostalgic about a memorable trip to Botswana on safari with a
group of animal enthusiasts.  I was happy when they were content to pause
and watch the animals interact rather than rush on to the next sighting.
I was very moved by the vast number of species we were shown and very
grateful to our excellent native guides.  I was very excited to follow a
lion hunt and amazed by the theatre of waiting scavengers.  At first I
found the heat overwhelming but as we got used to it, it was very enjoyable
and I would love to recapture this experience again.

I got lost on Blackpool beach when I was about four years old.  I can
remember feeling very scared.  I thought I would not see my mum again.
This made me very tearful.  This is nostalgic for me because I have been
back to Blackpool many times since then, and I always think of that time.

Annual family holiday.  Major extravagance of the year.  Parents and
brothers, train journey to sea-side, via London.  Carrying luggage through
crowds.  Usually holidayed at same resort but different B&Bs.  Excitement
of train journey, satisfaction of seeing some landmarks, able to move round
train carriage.  Anticipation of whole family trying to do as many good
activities together as possible.  Talking about holiday and previous
holiday on journey.  Happiness.  Feeling good.

I love the Lake District.  I have spent many holidays walking the fells,
usually in company, and, in the 1970s, I climbed, with my family, a fell
called Hay Stacks.  It was a magical place with a summit of tumbling rocks
and small tarns like a Lake District in miniature.  About 10 years ago, I
decided to climb Hay Stacks again on my own.  I met nobody on the way up or
down or on the summit.  It was a still day.  The mirrored tarns reflected
the surrounding rocks and the view of Buttemere and the North Western fells
was superb.  I sat and gazed for a long time, taking in the beauty and
peacefulness of my surroundings.  It brought back memories of another,
different life and it made me sad as I knew I was never likely to see that
view of the top of Hay Stacks again.

Catching minnows in the river.  Good times back in the childhood.  No
responsibilities, just a few of us and a net and jam jar.  Barefoot and
ankle deep in the water; waiting for the fish to appear.  Cold feet though
must scoop them up quickly and get them in the jar.  On edge to do it
quickly, mustnt let the fish die.  Put them back in the end alive, where
they should be its right.

My maternal grandfather was a village baker who worked on his own.  From a
very early age I was allowed to go into the bakehouse and help with making
the bread.  I had a white starched bakers apron for myself but the biggest
thing in my life then was when my grandfather had a half size bakers basket
made for me.  I was so proud to be the only person I knew who had one.
Grandfather had a bakers barrow on wheels and whenever possible I went
round with him, taking one loaf at a time in to the customers  happy days.

A day spent with my son on his return from two years abroad  a coastal
walk on a warm summer day in a beautiful landscape  Devon.  I was happy to
be having a pleasant time with my son  family relationships with him had
not always been free of aggravation.  I was pleased that neither of us
needed to show any antagonism or arrogance.  I felt no fear of being
totally open and honest with him.  We discussed many subjects in this
manner.  We were unhurried and sat above a marvellous seacliff in wonderful
conditions which we were both able to share before his departure once again
to his family and home in Australia.

Back to when in 20s (age) worked exploring for oil as engineer, excitement
of travel to Far East in jungleNorth Sumatra  Indonesia, new culture,
language, overcoming the challenge of working in jungle and being
successful.  In my 20s I could do anything I put my mind to and had the
energy to do  I feel the same inside but now I know I have limitations 
those days were although stressful at the time  remembered with good times
 you cant beat seeing a tiger on the way to the rig!

I remember with great fondness one holiday from the past that stands out
among the rest.  In Patara in Turkey we found an uncommercialised little
village which was hot and had a beach to die for.  In the evenings we could
enjoy a drink in the hotel roof-top bar, and wonder at the stars above.
During the day, along with our two children we soaked up the sun and the
kindness of the local people.  I have a longing, one day to return there
but worry that we may not find the same magic we once did.

One of my earliest memories is being taken by my Great Uncle to his
allotment near a busy railway junction near Reading.  Whilst some work was
done on the allotment most of the time was spent outside his shed watching
the trains, drinking tea out of enamel mugs and eating cheese sandwiches
made for us by my Great Aunt.  It was always a sunny day and I really
enjoyed hearing stories relating to his service on the London & South
Western Railway where he was employed as a fireman.  Another memory was the
amount of wild life in the area.  He would talk knowledgeably about all
manner of subjects which, at about the age of eight, I found fascinating.

A tour of India (1977) opened my eyes to poverty, wealth living side by side (extremes).  The people of India love the English which did surprise me, and they were very warm.  The environment in which people live is scary, squalor, unhealthy, but they emerge from shanty towns with immaculate dresses, school uniforms etc.

My event is a whole weekend around the 11th July which was my mothers birthday.  It always coincided with the Langley fete and we would take the children there together just as she had gone with my sister and her own mother.  They played games, took part in things to win prizes etc.  usual fete type activities and maybe a visit to the funfair as well.  On this weekend wed always have a strawberry birthday cake which Id make and wed sit in the garden with kids playing  weather permitting of course but in most of my memories the weather was good.  Wed chat and she would play games, draw pictures with the kids  she really loved them and didnt tire of these silly games.  My feelings about these times is that I didnt realised at the time how special they were.  I felt loved and supported  like the sun shone on me.  I went to the fete for the first time in about 10 years (my Mum died 2 years ago but she was paralysed and got upset about going there) last weekend.  I took my grandchildren.  It was a lovely day but I felt only sadness that I was alone.  If shed been there, she would have made it special for them as well.  I also felt sad that she had got ill and missed out on good times.  On reflection, I guess I have rose tinted glasses on a bit about these weekends  really thats probably what nostalgia is  memories that improve with time.

When my daughter Sian was 8 and my son Tom was 4; it was the summer before I returned to work.  It was a very hot day and there were loads of kids in my back garden during the day, playing in our paddling pool.  Three of the children were my friends children who lived at the house that backed onto ours.  At the time we used to see a lot of her and her husband, but they have since split up and moved and of course the kids are now adults like mine.  I suppose I sometimes think just how sad it was that they broke up as it seemed to affect the children as well.  Also my own daughter is now pregnant and this brings it home to me how quickly time passes.

Every summer holiday Sunday the whole family would spend the day at our local beach.  First job was to build a table and two benches in the sand for lunch for all of us except the baby in the carrycot!  We always had tomato soup out of two large thermos flasks, sandwiches and apples.  Another food item was chittering biscuits for when we came out of the sea and all sat on a rug with our towels around us.  At the end of the day we played beach cricket with the other families  usually about six or eight of them before heading home at about 6pm.  They always seemed to be fun filled days in the sunshine!

A beautiful fine summer evening on the beach, a barbecue with friends, all leaving University.  Lots of chatting and laughing.  Walking along the beach with my boyfriend, wondering what was coming next  would we see each other.  Eating and drinking as the sun goes down.  Lying on the beach, feeling the warmth of the sand and the breeze picking up from the sea and cooling us down.  Borrowing a jumper from someone to keep warm.  Blissful feelings, but nervous too and excited about the future.

The nostalgic event above was a trip to Egypt made 3 years ago.  I found the culture of that time (e.g. time of the Pharoahs) in Egypt was fascinating and I was amazed at the advanced civilisation those many years ago.  The most interesting was the Cairo museum, specifically the Tutankhamen exhibition.  I also found Abu Simbel very interesting.  I have explained the whole holiday as my nostalgic event.

A lovely warm glowing and happy feeling when thinking about a weekend about 20 years ago.  We had a large marquee in the garden, and on Saturday night had lots of people from our firm for a games night.  Great fun, good food, and everyone friendly.  Next afternoon, did tea for parents (gold wedding), lots of family and friends mainly older people, after tea they decided to do Olde Tyme Dancing and stayed very late.  Children did a little show for them, and everyone laughed, reminisced and went home late but happy.

I enjoy with fond memories the Sunday lunch times when I would meet up with my father and our close friends in the village pub prior to having Sunday lunch at Mums.  We enjoyed a few beers while righting the wrongs of the world and extolling or criticizing the virtues of the West Indies cricket team.  Part of the tradition was to buy a bottle of Mans brown ale for Mum to have with her lunch.  Those were great days and I remember them with great happiness.  Oh how sad that those days are gone.

Its a lovely summer morning, I am happy but just a little anxious about the childrens party later on in the day.  I am pleased to see the delight and excitement as the cards and presents are opened.  The tent is up in the garden, and I check the cakes I have made the day before, decide the look good and feel quite proud of my efforts.  Lots of noisy children arrive and run in and out, play games and squeal and shout and make lots of mess in the tent in the garden, glad I put the food out there for the birthday picnic.  Some hours later the doorbell rings and I breathe a sigh of relief when the children leave and I can relax and enjoy the evening.  What a lovely day we had. I love my family.

As a young girl I would pack up some tea things and go on my bike to the park with a friend to have tea.  We would take a rug and perhaps a game to play.  We enjoyed the freedom of being out and about and found it exciting and daring that we were on our own.  We would lie down on the blankets and hear rustling in the bushes (animals scratching around), and hoped that the animals were tame!

Visiting the street and park where I lived until 8 years old.  It is very difficult to describe these feelings, which is probably why the word nostalgia exists!  Pleasure in revisiting a familiar place evoking a wish and longing to get it back as it was, and reeling sad that the child me has gone forever.  An awareness of time passing and loss and how the present will be past sometime too: even an awareness of mortality and death.  Feeling amused in a way about the experience!

The day I met my partner was a sunny Sunday and I was scared.  My younger son was due to return to Afghanistan the next day and my elder son was going away to sea.
