We had arranged to meet for a drink but I couldnt face a room full of people so we went for a walk in the sunshine to the lock on the river.  We sat on a bench and talked and watched the water flow.

When I was single, living and working away from home, I would look forward to the enormous holidays.  I would travel to my family home and eagerly await spending time with my parents and brother.  I would visualise the Christmas decorations, the tree and presents.  I couldnt wait to be surrounded by familiar things and the people I loved.

My wedding took place when both of us were in our very early twenties.  We had been saving all our spare cash for three years in preparation for the wedding so we had plenty of time to prepare emotionally for married life.  The wedding itself was very low key because we didnt want to waste too much money on the day itself.  We invested all our savings in our first house.  Unfortunately, because we came from different branches of the Christian religion we were unable to choose a church to hold the wedding in.  Instead we were married by a Civil ceremony only.

My daughter was a late addition to our family, with two older brothers.  We fully expected her to be a third boy, so the surprise was great when a daughter was announced!  She was born in a very decrepit hospital in Taipei, Taiwan.  The hospital was actually demolished a couple of months later.  The whole experience was traumatic, but full of anecdotal nostalgia, the circumstances being so unusual.  She arrived by c-section and was the only Caucasian baby in the nursery, so she was definitely ours.  Her birth was the cause of much rejoicing in the family and amongst our friends, her brothers loved having a baby sister.

Last year my husband arranged for a long weekend in Newcastle.  Newcastle is the city where my dad was born who died when I was 10.  As a child I spent every Easter in Newcastle visiting family for a holiday and I hadnt really been back since my dad died.  When we arrived last year my husband said he wanted to take me to all the places I used to visit as a child.  Every day we did something different.  We visited the road where my grandparents lived and stood outside the house.  We went into the church where I was christened.  Visiting the beach at Whitley Bay was the most special moment.  My childhood memory was stopping in the high street in Whitley Bay and buying our baps and ham from the butchers and bakers who were next door to each other.  I couldnt believe it when we saw that they were still there.  We stopped and I bought baps and ham.  We then drove down to the beach.  There is still a tea bar there that does trays of tea for the beach, although no longer with a china tea service.  We sat on the beach having our lunch and listening to the children playing in the sea reminding them of me.  I then made my husband run up and down the sand dunes as I had done with my brother when we were children.  A very special moment.  A wonderful weekend that made me very happy but tinged with sadness to think what I used to have.

Every weekday morning I drive on the motorway to work.  I try to make the task as routine and the same as possible.  So I could even do it with my eyes closed.  So that it tires me the absolute minimum.  But I know that it is so dangerous that I cant relax too much but have to concentrate intensely.  Where the M25 goes off is scary.  I feel trapped with very few options and at the mercy of the stupidest of the cars around me.  It is an ordinary daily essential event.  I fear getting killed or injured.

I recently went to hospital as an inpatient for the first time in my life.  It was an experience that put me outside of my comfort zone.  I had to put myself in the hands of complete strangers and had little control over what happened.

I have been playing tennis for a long time and enjoy it every time I play.  For playing tennis I know that I have to go to the club.  What would urge me to play tennis in addition to enjoying it is the fitness and consequently the health it brings to me.

I have always painted nails, it is a job that needs to be done weekly, doesnt take too long but is always worth the time spent.  The first task is to remove the varnish, the smell of the remover is very strong, then cut and file the nails  this reshaping makes my nails feel different.  Two coats of nail varnish and my hands look different, very much fresher and smarter  I feel better when my nails are freshly painted.

Going to work at Heathrow Airport was an ordinary event for me, but there was never an ordinary day.  Every morning getting around 5am and setting off for Terminal One was a feature in itself.  I would leave my village in the dark and negotiate the same milk float at the same bridge every morning passing the same people all heading in different directions at the start of their day.

There would be a complete contrast at arriving in the Terminal, where bright lights and the stirrings of people arriving for their early flights.  Sometimes having to step around people just waking up, having spent the night on the floor.

The day would soon change as hundreds of people would start to pass by on their way to catch flights.  The noise would increase and before long the whole place would be in a sort of perpetual panic until night would again restore some calm...
This was my ordinary event for 35 years.

I recall a shopping trip to Wembley with my parents.  We went by car.  I was allowed to choose several things to wear in C&As including a red pinafore and checked blouse.  I felt really happy with my new things.  We went and had lunch and I had a prawn cocktail which I thought was great.

My ordinary moment would be driving to my office job down the road from where I live it was in an oil terminal.  The car park was rubbish and you would often get blocked in.  The offices then moved to Aylesbury which was about 26 miles away.  I done this journey every day for 5 years and met lots of friends, we used to go out lots and had a real laugh.  I used to drive as escort then that would often break down my friend used to think it so funny.

Going shopping to buy basic essentials of clothing.  Dont like going shopping and trying to get it done as quickly as possible.  Visiting the shops in order, queuing to pay.  Feel frustrated when have to queue a long time.  Pleased when I find exactly what I want.  Usually pay bill at this time in bank  again in a frustration when queuing.  It takes so long to key in the cheques to the account.  Reward myself with a Starbucks  thats a nice feeling and something I look forward to!

In recent years, I and my husband have been regularly playing golf, and last year we decided to join the club.  Since then we have made lots of new friends, and really enjoy the social life.  We enter many of the competitions, which involves a lot of team work, and to be able to do this, especially when winning a match at our age, is a great feeling of achievement.  It is an ordinary event but with much pleasure and enjoyment.

Every couple of days I walk round to the local paper shop to buy a 4 pint bottle of milk.  The same man always serves me in the shop and he always greets me the same way.  I always say the same thing to him and he always says the same thing to me.  I suppose I find this reassuring but it is also very boring!

List in hand as I rush to the car.  In order to complete the weekly shopping at Sainsburys I choose the nearest Chislehurst branch.  I make it a challenge to get around as fast as possible.  Home, if possible for morning coffee or some other reward.  Theres always something out of stock so I usually return slightly irritated but glad to have completed the task.  On completion it makes me feel satisfied as the house is well stocked and I wont have to return for a while.

Going to the supermarket to buy food for a birthday party.  The weather was windy and it was also raining and it was difficult to find a car parking space in the supermarket car park without getting wet.  This outing should have been straightforward but it was spoilt by the weather. I was worried about the supermarket goods getting wet as I took them back to the car.

I am walking to work, worried about the weather, if it rains, I am going to get soaked and I will be late on duty.  I am now rushing and also worrying about work.  Is it going to be a busy shift or a quiet one.  Then I say to myself what is the point of worrying about this, take it as it comes!

Being now retired 10 years, I have chosen a typical day at work.  I would
regularly walk to work and when I arrived I would be grateful that my
nurse/receptionist would have everything prepared for the day.  Being an
orthodontist my work was rarely stressful, as my patients were usually
willing and keen to be treated.  I got great satisfaction from my work but
occasionally I was frustrated when instructions were not followed by the
child or parent.  Generally I worked calmly and rarely was I challenged as
I could refer very difficult cases.  I was relieved that most paper-work
was done by my staff, whom I trusted to get it right.

I love gardening and watching things grow.  It gives me great pleasure to
plant bulbs and plants and see them grow into lovely blooms.  This is a
wonderful feeling it gives me great pleasure.  I spend a lot of time in my
garden so this is an ordinary event for me.

Asked to buy bread at the local bakers.  Walk along busy roads and choose
usual split tin loaf in friendly family run business.  A reassurance from
staff that choice is right.  Return home with loaf, usually warm fresh
baked, tucked under am.  I feel responsible having been sent out on errand
as last loaf eaten by family too quickly.  Some resentment that I was not
involved in eating last loaf.  Familiar experience and feelings suggest to
me now, how emotional I was as a child.

Trips to supermarket are necessary.  They offer ample parking and, they
say, a wide choice of goods at competitive prices.  Such a trip should be
convenient and even enjoyable.  However, on every trip, I cannot help
noticing that my shopping is being manipulated at every turn.  The layout
of the store is designed to lead me past the maximum number of displays of
goods.  The layout of the shelves is designed to draw my eye towards the
goods they want me to buy.  The choice of goods is designed to influence my
selection.  The price of goods is structured to suggest what I ought to buy
and I am denied any real opportunity to compare prices and quality with
those in rival supermarkets or set by independent traders.  Consequently, I
am aware that I am buying goods that I did not necessarily come for at
prices that are probably more than I need to pay.  Supermarket shopping is
certainly convenient but I come away from each trip aware that I have been
a willing victim who has been duped again.

A multifuel stove in the dining room keeps the house warm.  It has to be
fed coal to keep it going and cleaned of ash as well.  Raking the embers
and putting on coal renews the cycle, there is me keeping it going,
maintaining the warmth therefore the comfort that it produces.  I feel
warm, people in the house feel warm and snug.  No complaints from the rest
of the household so I have achieved something and they are happier.

For many years one of my hobbies was gardening.  In particular I loved
hanging baskets.  A trip to the fuchsia nursery and the selection of
suitable plants was an afternoon outing.  Then came the planting out 
fitting the liner, then filling with compost.  It was then a question of
selecting the plants for each one.  Dancing Flame, a lovely pale orange
was a favourite.  Four plants round the outside and one in the centre 
that was the norm.  Then after several weeks of careful tending  a blaze
of colour for months!

I cycle to & from work daily.  I leave early because I dont like to be
late & I like plenty of time to recover before starting work.  I sometimes
leave work late due to my need to see jobs completed & I feel guilty to my
wife over this.  I enjoy the journey to & from work even though a steep
climb is involved  I enjoy the fact that I can cycle up a steep hill.  I
am very careful & nervous of the traffic & use back roads when possible.  I
am courteous to road users & pedestrians  this to improve the bad image of
cyclists generally.  However there have been instances of my bad language
when confronted by an inconsiderate motorist!!

Weekly shop is a total chore, its so routine, boring takes too long and
basically get really annoyed when people cant decide on which butter to
buy and just stand there!  I want to get in/out as quickly as possible 
but never seems to happen.  I know what I want  but takes too long, I know
what I like  only occasionally is there something of interest  I have
better things to do  get impatient  always crowded  too many people 
push/in the way!

As a season ticket holder at St Marys Stadium, I recently attended a game
between my team Southampton and Peterborough United.  I was very excited at
the prospect that if we won it would take us up in to the top sixth in the
league.  I went for a couple of pints first, then met up with a mate in the
ground to soak up the atmosphere.  The ground was buzzing.  Then the game
started and so did the frustration as chance after chance went begging.
After the first goal that changed to celebration.  After a heart pounding
90 minutes we won 4-1 and I went home very satisfied indeed.

As a child my parents took me on our annual holiday to Scotland.  We
visited the same places and stayed with the same welcoming family every
year for about ten consecutive years.  The journey to Scotland involved
catching a coach to London and another overnight coach to Glasgow.  I can
remember always being ill on the coach going, but never coming home.  I
would watch the coach speedometer and tell my father how fast the coach was
going until the driver put his cap over the dial.  Fish and chips were
always on the menu on seaside trips always to the same place.  My favourite
food in Scotland was Clootie Dumpling, which was cooked in a large copper.

Cutting of grass is a satisfactory event, this also provides a tidy lawn, home and tidy garden.  Lines provide a regular and controlled situation.  Trimming of the edges is the final portion to achieve the complete finish.  Disposal of cuttings is a bore, but needs to be done.

As part of my work I support people to carry out management tasks in further education colleges.  The event Ill focus on is supporting a new manager to self assess the strengths and areas for development in her curriculum area.  I ask her questions about the evidence she has to tease out from her what this means and to support her to make judgements.  My feelings about this are that it seems very easy for me and I find it hard to see why some people find it so difficult although I probably found it difficult a long time ago but I dont remember as it seemed very logical to me.  Anyway, Im happy that they do find it difficult because that means I get enjoyable work to support them.  I feel quite powerful/knowledgeable in that situation and am very conscious of using a mentoring approach so that people can arrive at the answer themselves.  This kind of work appeals to the supportive/mothering side of my nature I think and so I feel happy in the role, especially when I get positive feedback from the person  it is very rewarding.

For the past couple of months I have been going to visit my mother, with my sister, every Saturday morning.  My mother has been in care homes for the past five years.  Unfortunately the residential home that she was in, could no longer cope with her, so we had to find her a new home to cope with her worsening Alzheimers and her nursing needs.  We had an horrific experience when she was placed in a horrible home for a few weeks and we had to fight to get somewhere else.  My mother is now the happiest she has been in years and I actually look forward to seeing her with my sister Kathleen (Kangeen renamed by my daughter when she was a toddler).  We have a good laugh every week, amongst the completely mad conversation that takes place!

I do not like shopping  especially for clothes.  Food purchases in a supermarket cause me irritation when they move items around and are not where I would logically look for them.  When going shopping the first problem is parking, then finding a trolley and discovering that you do not have the 1 coin needed to get the trolley!  The final straw is on your way out you remember that the one thing you really wanted but had not written on your list is the one you have forgotten to buy!!

I remember walking to school with friends wearing blue dresses in the summer.  I had red shoes on  lovely shiny, smart new shoes.  I used to walk with my sister and two other friends.  It was a lovely sunny day and I loved going to school.  There were lots of roses in the gardens and I used to pick the rose petals and smell them and hold them they were so soft and velvety.  I loved the colour and the feel.  I used to look for hairy caterpillars and hold them too.  I talked to all the cats and dogs in gardens on the way and spent ages stroking the cats on their walks and trying to make them follow me.

The ordinary event above is playing golf.  I play at least one time or twice a week.  I really enjoy the event as I know it helps me keep fitter and I can meet friends and make new friends in games that I play.  In competitions I find that the competitiveness is an added experience that I enjoy.  The specific event that I recalled was an ordinary game I played last week.

Going shopping for groceries is a very ordinary and boring event.  Having done this for many years is probably what makes it so boring.  When in Tescos I am cross when articles are moved; I have to queue at the check-out, and I detest being rushed to get it all packed.  Then having struggled, I have to put it all away  ugh.  Even with online shopping, I still have to put it all away  what a frustrating activity!

I recall the experience of regular shopping trips to the local supermarket with my wife.  The chore always fills me with depression and boredom.  Boredom because I could be doing something far more interesting; depression because of the overwhelming claustrophobia being endured.  I feel imprisoned and restless.  Why must my wife examine every article in minute detail before swapping it for another one?  And I just know that my queue will be the slowest and the till roll will run out before my turn comes to pay.  Oh yes, and why is it that intending only to buy a bottle of milk and half a dozen eggs that I find I have a full trolley costing 120!

I looked out of the window, surveyed the back garden and decided reluctantly that as the weather was dry, the grass green but long, that I should mow the lawn.  I collected the mower from the garage and set to work.  I felt resentful of having to do this chore as I really just wanted to sit in the nice warm conservatory reading my book.  I cut the grass, dead headed flowers, watered some dry pots, cleaned the mower and the re-arranged my pots of red dahlias so they would be in full view of the kitchen window.  I admired the neater lawn and beautiful flowers and felt pleased with the result but disappointed that now the sun was less hot, the day shorter and soon time for dinner and I still hadnt started my book.

Supermarket shopping just before Christmas: Arriving at the supermarket with anticipation of all the nice things Im going to buy, but decision making involved in choosing what!  It is so crowded that it becomes frustrating that I cant reach the shelves.  At the end of the shopping I reach the endless queues at the check out desks  mustering as much patience as possible.

Shopping for fresh food in M&S.  A slight feeling of dread as I enter the shop and a press of people: feel better the fewer people are there.  A desire to be quick and get it done but people and things get in the way.  I want to see if something new catches my eye, but it usually doesnt so I have to focus on what I need to buy to keep the household going: if I see something new Ill stop and take a good look otherwise I grab the groceries.  Im relieved, if not elated, when I leave the shop.

My breakfast last Tuesday was very ordinary.  My partner made us both tea and we drank it listening to the Today programme on radio 4.  When the tea was drunk, I had my bath and a couple of slices of toast.  After dressing we left the house together and I went to work in Langley.

A visit to the supermarket is a regular routine.  However, this time it seemed even more frustrating.  I was trying to buy specific items and everything I wanted was not in stock.  I was getting more and more fed up and angry that I couldnt find the stuff I wanted.  Eventually I had to settle for different items.

Our four month old puppy, Amber, has just started going for short walks to the park.  We are delighted by this because one of the major benefits of owning a dog is being able to walk out with it in the countryside.  We drive a very short distance to the park and release the dog off the lead so that she can enjoy all the new smells and experiences of the park.  We are a bit concerned because the puppy is still very young and we are not certain that she is fully trained to respond to our calls if there is a problem.  We therefore walk the dog away from the lake because we know she loves water.

As people need to eat to survive, someone has to prepare the food.  As a housewife, this usually falls to my lot.  I have a beautiful kitchen, with every modern convenience to aid me in my task of preparing meals.  However, I hate cooking, it is repetitive, boring and provides me with no mental stimulation whatsoever.  Also, as a vegetarian, I do not enjoy handling and cooking meat products.  The occasion I am recalling involved cooking fish (for my husband), stir-fried vegetables and French fries for us both.  I also ate cheese.  When cooking I listened to an audio book to relieve the tedium.

An ordinary time in my life was as a child every Saturday we used to visit my grandparents.  My mum was one of ten children so it was a house full of people.  Every Saturday the whole family would gather in their house in Wraysbury for lunch and dinner.  We always had the same food, shepherds pie and rice pudding.  We always played football in the garden and went for a walk down to the park.  When we left my granddad always gave all the grandchildren a silver sixpence.   This was a very ordinary day of the week but also a special one.
